moves.1. e4: This game was played on the German chess site schacharena.de. It is interesting for a cross pin in the middle game.
moves.1... d6 2. Bc4: A bit unusual, the standard moves are d4 and Nc3 after black's Nf6.
moves.2... Nf6 3. d3: Still Nc3 could have been played here.
moves.7. c4: There are some weak dark squares in white's camp already: d4, b4.
moves.8. Ba4: White forgets to develop his pieces.
moves.11. Bxd7 Qxd7 12. Qd2 Nc5: Threatens a knight fork on b3.
moves.14. f3: Weakens one more dark square: e3. Now there are several dark diagonals in white's camp open for black to exploit.
moves.14... bxc4 15. dxc4 Rfb8: Black searches for inititative on the queen side.
moves.16. Nf4 Nb3 17. Ra2 Qc6: The queen enters the queen side action.
moves.18. Qc2 Nxc1 19. Qxc1 Bh6: Pins the knight to the queen. Here an exciting game takes its course!
moves.20. Nd5: ! If 20...Bxc1 then 21.Nxe7  and forks king and queen.
moves.20... Qc5+: The queen goes on the dark diagonal towards the white king.
moves.21. Ne3: A cross pin!! Normally this is lethal, but white finds here again and again a way to hold on.
moves.52... Rxd6 53. Kc4: The rest was blitz, playing for the opponent to lose on time. But fortunately 2 min were enough for me to get the game into the safe mate-harbour.
moves.53... a2 54. Kxc5 Rg6 55. Kc4 a1=Q 56. K: Closes the king in. The only thing now to avoid is stalemate!
